Something which has bothered me for some time now is the lack of 
historic =
record keeping of the early tsubako (pre Edo).  With the 
exception of the =
Goto there doesn't seem to be too much of a record.  
Now there was a recor=
d of the sword smiths.  This is why I question 
the 'relative' value of the=
 tsubako before Edo.  After the civil war 
period artistic merit became mor=
e important and all of a sudden we 
see records of the tsubako.  It may be =
possible that we are 
dogmatizing the whole iron tsuba field, in other word=
s making it more 
important than it was ever viewed by the people of those =
times.  Now 
it is also important to remember that there is nothing wrong w=
ith 
recognizing artistic beauty where it was not appreciated before.  I 
j=
ust have to wonder if sometimes we are overdoing it, that's all.  
The 'bea=
utiful' tekotsu bumplies on the mimi were just not worth the 
time or effor=
t to smooth off, and the 'surface texturing' was done to 
hide the irregula=
rities in the metal.
